10904Journal of Inorganic and Organometallic Polymers and MaterialsJ Inorg Organomet Polym1574-14431574-1451Springer USBostons10904-009-9279-3927910.1007/s10904-009-9279-3ArticleAn Interesting Complex: [Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)]nWangJian12aXuXingyou12MaWeixing1YinFujun12GuoTeng1LuLude2YangXujie2WangXin2grid.443480.f0000000418000658Huaihai Institute of Technology222005JiangsuPeople’s Republic of Chinagrid.410579.e0000000091169901Materials Chemistry LaboratoryNanjing University of Science and Technology210094NanjingPeople’s Republic of Chinawangj@hhit.edu.cn1352009920091934014052742009269200827420091352009© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 20092009Abstract

A novel coordination polymer [Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)]n (where l-trp and d-trp are l-tryptophan and d-tryptophan or (S)-2-amino-3-(3-indolyl)propionic acid and (R)-2-amino-3-(3-indolyl)propionic acid) was prepared by a solvent-thermal method and characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The compound(monoclinic space group P2(1)/c with a = 19.759(2) Å, b = 5.2496(10) Å, c = 9.7594(16) Å, β = 97.2760(10)°, Z = 2) shows a two-dimensional plane structure. The crystallized coordination polymer has a centrosymmetric space group. Each Cd2+ ion coordinates with a pair of racemes, and the complex is a mesomer. Although l-trp was used, both l-trp and d-trp appear in the complex.

Introduction

Cadmium is an environmental pollution source. It is easily accumulated in body and is poisonous. Decreasing the absorption of cadmium from the stomach and intestine by means of the lustration cadmium effect of a chelate is one of the detoxifcation approaches to a cadmium poisoning [1].

The Cd2+ ion coordinated with the amino acid is an important way to eliminate cadmium ion pollution to the environment. Therefore, investigation on the stability of Cd(II) and amino acid complex is vitally important in environmental protection and medical science.

The characteristics and variation law of an metallic ion–amino acid complex reflect the nutrition, growth, health and intriguing biochemistry changes in organisms [2–5]. To date, many cadmium(II)–amino acid complexes have been synthesized [6–14].

Bidentate or multidentate ligands are an important part in metal–amino acid complexes. Such ligands dominate the space between the metal atoms and the dimension of the crystal structure. Although many metal–amino acid complexes have already been synthesized, it is still quite difficult to grow single-crystals of relevant complexes. This is probably related to the fact that amino acids easily decompose. However, the bonds formed in metal–amino acid coordination polymers are usually very resistant to free-radical cleavage reactions and exhibit high thermal stability. Furthermore, metals often have variable valences, thus leading to a variety of frameworks to fulfill special needs such as electrical conductivity, magnetism, photomechanism, host–guest chemistry, ion exchange, shape specificity and catalysis [15].

The hydrothermal reaction process has been applied to the synthesis of metal coordination networks [16, 17]. The method is well known for its ability to promote crystal growth and has been widely adopted in the preparation of many solid-state inorganic materials and in the synthesis of coordination compounds. Furthermore, hydrothermal reactions often produce metastable compounds that may otherwise not be accessible by conventional methods. Coordination compounds generated under supercritical conditions are often difficult to obtain by conventional solution synthesis [16–18]. Hydrothermal processing also has long been utilized to make advanced ceramic powders with controlled homogeneity and properties at relatively low cost. The method maintains both the particles in solution throughout the process and allows a high-temperature step to anneal out defects, which result in improved properties of the product [19]. With respect to reaction mechanism, the hydrothermal reaction is in accord with the nucleation model. Under comparatively extreme conditions imposed by a hydrothermal reaction, the viscosity of water is reduced and the diffusion process is enhanced so that the solvent can extract the solid component and crystal growth becomes possible.

In this report the preparation and characterization of a tryptophan coordination polymer, [Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)]n, will be described. In addition, we will discuss the interesting phenomenon that although l-trp is used, both l- and d-trp appeared in the complex.

ExperimentalSynthesis of [Cd(<sc>l</sc>-trp) (<sc>d</sc>-trp)]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub>

All the reagents were of AR grade and used without further purification. l-trp (1.0 mmol, 0.2043 g) was dissolved in methanol (10 mL) and stirred for 10 min at room temperature. Cadmium acetate dihydrate (0.5 mmol, 0.1337 g) was dissolved in methanol (10 mL) and added dropwise to the above solution for 0.5 h with stirring. The resulting mixture was put into a Teflon®-lined stainless steel autoclave (25 mL capacity) under autogenous pressure and heated to 165 °C for 72 h. The autoclave was then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 3.0 °C/h. Colorless rhombic sheet crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography were obtained; yield of 48%. The crystalline material is difficult to dissolve in water, methanol, ethanol, ether, acetonitrile, DMF or DMSO.

C, H and N analysis was obtained with a PE2400-II Elemental Analyser: Calcd. (%) for C22H22CdN4O4: C, 50.93; H, 4.27; N, 10.80. Found: C, 50.85; H, 4.20; N, 10.88.

Infrared spectrum of the complex obtained with a WGH-30A (KBr pellet, cm−1 (intensity): 3407.7(str), 3362.5(wk), 3273.6(med), 2906.9(med), 1589.7(str), 1455.5(med), 1412.2(med), 1318.8(med), 1223.4(med), 1168.0(wk), 1090.4(med), 1043,5(med), 919.0(wk), 800.6(med), 740.1(str), 581.9(med), 483.7(med). The relevant frequencies of l-trp and [Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)]n are summarized in Table 1 with the important assignments.

Structure Determination of [Cd(<sc>l</sc>-trp) (<sc>d</sc>-trp)]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub> [<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR20">20</xref>–<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="CR22">22</xref>]

A single crystal of the complex with dimensions of 0.26 mm × 0.20 mm × 0.11 mm was selected for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Data collection was performed on a BRUKER SMART 1000 CCD area detector equipped with a graphite-monochromatized MoKa radiation (λ = 0.07l073 nm) at 298(2)K. The data were corrected for Lp factors. The structure of the compound was solved by direct methods to locate all the non-H atoms from the trial structure and then refined anisotropically with SHELXTL using full-matrix least-squares procedure. All the H atoms were geometrically fixed at calculated positions. Data collection: Bruker SMART. Cell refinement: Bruker SMART. Data reduction: Bruker SAINT. Program(s) used to solve structure: SHELXS-97 (Sheldrick 1990). Program(s) used to refine structure: SHELXL97 (Sheldrick 1997). Molecular graphics: Bruker SHELXTL. Software used to prepare material for publication: Bruker SHELXTL. The final cycle of refinement converged to R and wR (w = 1/[σ2(Fo2) + (0.0444P)2 + 0.7006P]), where P = (Fo2 + 2Fc2)/3, (Δ/σ)max = 0.001, Δρmax = 0.80e Å−3, Δρmin = −0.35 e Å−3. The related crystallographic data of title complex specified in Table 2.

Results and Discussion

The Selected bond lengths (Å) and angles (°) of the complex [Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)]n are listed in Table 3.

Scheme 1 and Fig. 1 are the molecular structure of the cadmium complex, and Fig. 2 shows the packing diagram of the cadmium complex in a unit cell.

The Cd(II) ion is six-coordinate to form a octahedron. The Cd(II) ions lie across the centers of complex and respectively integrate with four neutral tryptophan molecules: two l-trp and two d-trp. The complex shows a two-dimensional structure along the bc orientation assembled by bridging the oxygen of the carboxyl and the cadmium ion into chains of ‘···–O–C–O–Cd–O–C–O–Cd···’ interactions (see Figs. 3, 4, 5). Each unit cell contains two [Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)] coordination units. l-trp and d-trp are chiral ligands in the complex, which crystallizes in centrosymmetric space group. In the molecular structure of [Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)]n, the cadmium ion is coordinated by two N atoms and two O atoms from a l-trp and a d-trp, respectively, and two O atoms from another two carboxy groups of adjacent position l-trp and d-trp moieties (Figs. 1, 2). The equatorial Cd–O bond lengths are Cd1–O1: 2.263 (3) Å, Cd1–O2: 2.350 (3) Å. The axial Cd–N distance is 2.324 (3) Å. The angles in the octahedron are ∠O1i–Cd1–O1 = ∠O2ii–Cd1–O2iii = 180.0 (13)°, ∠O1i–Cd1–O2ii = ∠O1–Cd1–O2iii = 85.80 (11)°, ∠O1–Cd1–O2ii = ∠O1i–Cd1–O2iii = 94.20 (11)°, ∠O1i–Cd1–N1i = ∠O1–Cd1–N1 = 75.31 (11)°, ∠O1–Cd1–N1i = ∠O1i–Cd1–N1 = 104.69 (11)°, ∠O2ii–Cd1–N1i = ∠O2iii–Cd1–N1 = 89.55 (11)°, ∠O2iii–Cd1–N1i = ∠O2ii–Cd1–N1 = 90.45 (11)°, ∠N1i–Cd1–N1 = 180.00 (10)°, respectively. The structure shows that each Cd(II) atom exhibits a slightly deformed octahedral environment with four oxygen atoms from four different l-trp and d-trp molecules in the equatorial plane, as well as two nitrogen atoms from l-trp and a d-trp molecules at the axial positions. Bonds lengths and angles agree with literature-accepted values. Since each Cd2+ ion coordinates with a pair of racemes, the complex is a mesomer. Consequently the crystallized coordination polymer has a centrosymmetric space group.

Interestingly, both l-trp and d-trp were observed in the complex although l-trp was used as the unique starting material. It is noteworthy that l-trp is not easy to racemize. Our findings indicate a positive correlation between racemization and pH, temperature or reaction time [23–27]. Although we do not have a complete explanation for the conversion of l-trp to d-trp, we speculate that, under the influence of steric hindrance and solvent, some l-trp is converted to d-trp in order to satisfy symmetry requirements. In fact, this assumption is confirmed experimentally since only [M(d-trp) (l-trp)]n is obtained when the water-thermal and organic-solvent thermal methods are used [28–34]. Furthermore, when l-trp is used, a mixture of DL-tryptophan crystals is observed in the presence of neodymium carbonate and the mixed solvent of MeOH and H2O.

The symmetry of [Cd(l-trp)2]n crystal structure is lower than that of [Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)]n since the latter is centrosymmetric. Relative to [Cd(l-trp)2]n and [Cd(d-trp)2]n, a lower energy and higher stability is achieved, which is attributed to the spatial arrangement of l-trp and d-trp in the [Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)]n crystal structure. Thus, there is enough pressure, temperature and reaction time under solvent-thermal conditions to transform l-trp to d-trp gradually and partially via an enamine intermediate [23, 24]. We reason that there is a dynamic equilibrium existed between l-trp and d-trp, and the equilibrium can readily shift to a more stable configuration by crystallization or precipitation from solution. Consequently, self-assembly that generates a supramolecular polymer, {[Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)]n}, may be a typical cooperative process.

Conclusions

A novel two-dimensional double chain structure of cadmium (II), [Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)]n, was synthesized and structurally characterized. The complex crystallizes in a monoclinic system and belong to the P2(1)/c space group. Each Cd(II) atom is located in the center of a deformed octahedral configuration. The six vertexes of the deformed octahedron form a 4O + 2N coordination number environment with four oxygen atoms from four different l-trp and d-trp molecules; two nitrogen atoms from a l-trp and a d-trp molecule. Each Cd(II) ion coordinates with a pair of racemes, and the complex is a mesomer. The crystallized coordination polymer has a centrosymmetric space group.

The angles in the octahedron are ∠O1i-Cd1-O1 = ∠O2ii-Cd1-O2iii = 180.0 (13)°, ∠O1i-Cd1-O2ii = ∠O1-Cd1-O2iii = 85.80 (11)°, ∠O1-Cd1-O2ii = ∠O1i-Cd1-O2iii = 94.20 (11)°, ∠O1i-Cd1-N1i = ∠O1-Cd1-N1 = 75.31 (11)°, ∠O1-Cd1-N1i = ∠O1i-Cd1-N1 = 104.69 (11)°, ∠O2ii-Cd1-N1i = ∠O2iii-Cd1-N1 = 89.55 (11)°, ∠O2iii-Cd1-N1i = ∠O2ii-Cd1-N1 = 90.45 (11)°, ∠N1i-Cd1-N1 = 180.00 (10)°, respectively. The structure shows that each Cd(II) atom exhibits a slightly deformed octahedral environment with four oxygen atoms from four different l-trp and d-trp molecules in the equatorial plane, as well as two nitrogen atoms from l-trp and a d-trp molecules at the axial positions. Bonds lengths and angles agree with literature-accepted values. Since each Cd2+ ion coordinates with a pair of racemes, the complex is a mesomer. Consequently the crystallized coordination polymer has a centrosymmetric space group.Interestingly, both l-trp and d-trp were observed in the complex although l-trp was used as the unique starting material. It is noteworthy that l-trp is not easy to racemize. Our findings indicate a positive correlation between racemization and pH, temperature or reaction time [23-27]. Although we do not have a complete explanation for the conversion of l-trp to d-trp, we speculate that, under the influence of steric hindrance and solvent, some l-trp is converted to d-trp in order to satisfy symmetry requirements. In fact, this assumption is confirmed experimentally since only [M(d-trp) (l-trp)]n is obtained when the water-thermal and organic-solvent thermal methods are used [28-34]. Furthermore, when l-trp is used, a mixture of DL-tryptophan crystals is observed in the presence of neodymium carbonate and the mixed solvent of MeOH and H2O.The symmetry of [Cd(l-trp)2]n crystal structure is lower than that of [Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)]n since the latter is centrosymmetric. Relative to [Cd(l-trp)2]n and [Cd(d-trp)2]n, a lower energy and higher stability is achieved, which is attributed to the spatial arrangement of l-trp and d-trp in the [Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)]n crystal structure. Thus, there is enough pressure, temperature and reaction time under solvent-thermal conditions to transform l-trp to d-trp gradually and partially via an enamine intermediate [23, 24]. We reason that there is a dynamic equilibrium existed between l-trp and d-trp, and the equilibrium can readily shift to a more stable configuration by crystallization or precipitation from solution. Consequently, self-assembly that generates a supramolecular polymer, {[Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)]n}, may be a typical cooperative process.ConclusionsA novel two-dimensional double chain structure of cadmium (II), [Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)]n, was synthesized and structurally characterized. The complex crystallizes in a monoclinic system and belong to the P2(1)/c space group. Each Cd(II) atom is located in the center of a deformed octahedral configuration. The six vertexes of the deformed octahedron form a 4O + 2N coordination number environment with four oxygen atoms from four different l-trp and d-trp molecules; two nitrogen atoms from a l-trp and a d-trp molecule. Each Cd(II) ion coordinates with a pair of racemes, and the complex is a mesomer. The crystallized coordination polymer has a centrosymmetric space group.References1.J Gao, Synthesis, Structure and Antimicrobial Activity Study on New Complexes Derived from Polyamine. The compound(monoclinic space group P2(1)/c with a = 19.759(2) Å, b = 5.2496(10) Å, c = 9.7594(16) Å, β = 97.2760(10)°, Z = 2) shows a two-dimensional plane structure. The crystallized coordination polymer has a centrosymmetric space group. Each Cd2+ ion coordinates with a pair of racemes, and the complex is a mesomer. Although l-trp was used, both l-trp and d-trp appear in the complex.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A novel coordination polymer [Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)]n (where l-trp and d-trp are l-tryptophan and d-tryptophan or (S)-2-amino-3-(3-indolyl)propionic acid and (R)-2-amino-3-(3-indolyl)propionic acid) was prepared by a solvent-thermal method and characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The compound(monoclinic space group P2(1)/c with a = 19.759(2) Å, b = 5.2496(10) Å, c = 9.7594(16) Å, β = 97.2760(10)°, Z = 2) shows a two-dimensional plane structure. The crystallized coordination polymer has a centrosymmetric space group. Each Cd2+ ion coordinates with a pair of racemes, and the complex is a mesomer. Although l-trp was used, both l-trp and d-trp appear in the complex.

elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Cadmium is an environmental pollution source. It is easily accumulated in body and is poisonous. Decreasing the absorption of cadmium from the stomach and intestine by means of the lustration cadmium effect of a chelate is one of the detoxifcation approaches to a cadmium poisoning [1].

elements.content: The Cd2+ ion coordinated with the amino acid is an important way to eliminate cadmium ion pollution to the environment. Therefore, investigation on the stability of Cd(II) and amino acid complex is vitally important in environmental protection and medical science.

elements.content: The characteristics and variation law of an metallic ion–amino acid complex reflect the nutrition, growth, health and intriguing biochemistry changes in organisms [2–5]. To date, many cadmium(II)–amino acid complexes have been synthesized [6–14].
elements.clean_text: The characteristics and variation law of an metallic ion-amino acid complex reflect the nutrition, growth, health and intriguing biochemistry changes in organisms [2-5]. To date, many cadmium(II)-amino acid complexes have been synthesized [6-14].

elements.content: Bidentate or multidentate ligands are an important part in metal–amino acid complexes. Such ligands dominate the space between the metal atoms and the dimension of the crystal structure. Although many metal–amino acid complexes have already been synthesized, it is still quite difficult to grow single-crystals of relevant complexes. This is probably related to the fact that amino acids easily decompose. However, the bonds formed in metal–amino acid coordination polymers are usually very resistant to free-radical cleavage reactions and exhibit high thermal stability. Furthermore, metals often have variable valences, thus leading to a variety of frameworks to fulfill special needs such as electrical conductivity, magnetism, photomechanism, host–guest chemistry, ion exchange, shape specificity and catalysis [15].

Such ligands dominate the space between the metal atoms and the dimension of the crystal structure. Although many metal-amino acid complexes have already been synthesized, it is still quite difficult to grow single-crystals of relevant complexes. This is probably related to the fact that amino acids easily decompose. However, the bonds formed in metal-amino acid coordination polymers are usually very resistant to free-radical cleavage reactions and exhibit high thermal stability. Furthermore, metals often have variable valences, thus leading to a variety of frameworks to fulfill special needs such as electrical conductivity, magnetism, photomechanism, host-guest chemistry, ion exchange, shape specificity and catalysis [15].

elements.content: The hydrothermal reaction process has been applied to the synthesis of metal coordination networks [16, 17]. The method is well known for its ability to promote crystal growth and has been widely adopted in the preparation of many solid-state inorganic materials and in the synthesis of coordination compounds. Furthermore, hydrothermal reactions often produce metastable compounds that may otherwise not be accessible by conventional methods. Coordination compounds generated under supercritical conditions are often difficult to obtain by conventional solution synthesis [16–18]. Hydrothermal processing also has long been utilized to make advanced ceramic powders with controlled homogeneity and properties at relatively low cost. The method maintains both the particles in solution throughout the process and allows a high-temperature step to anneal out defects, which result in improved properties of the product [19]. With respect to reaction mechanism, the hydrothermal reaction is in accord with the nucleation model. Under comparatively extreme conditions imposed by a hydrothermal reaction, the viscosity of water is reduced and the diffusion process is enhanced so that the solvent can extract the solid component and crystal growth becomes possible.

The method maintains both the particles in solution throughout the process and allows a high-temperature step to anneal out defects, which result in improved properties of the product [19]. With respect to reaction mechanism, the hydrothermal reaction is in accord with the nucleation model. Under comparatively extreme conditions imposed by a hydrothermal reaction, the viscosity of water is reduced and the diffusion process is enhanced so that the solvent can extract the solid component and crystal growth becomes possible.

elements.content: All the reagents were of AR grade and used without further purification. l-trp (1.0 mmol, 0.2043 g) was dissolved in methanol (10 mL) and stirred for 10 min at room temperature. Cadmium acetate dihydrate (0.5 mmol, 0.1337 g) was dissolved in methanol (10 mL) and added dropwise to the above solution for 0.5 h with stirring. The resulting mixture was put into a Teflon®-lined stainless steel autoclave (25 mL capacity) under autogenous pressure and heated to 165 °C for 72 h. The autoclave was then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 3.0 °C/h. Colorless rhombic sheet crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography were obtained; yield of 48%. The crystalline material is difficult to dissolve in water, methanol, ethanol, ether, acetonitrile, DMF or DMSO.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Synthesis of [Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)]n

All the reagents were of AR grade and used without further purification. l-trp (1.0 mmol, 0.2043 g) was dissolved in methanol (10 mL) and stirred for 10 min at room temperature. Cadmium acetate dihydrate (0.5 mmol, 0.1337 g) was dissolved in methanol (10 mL) and added dropwise to the above solution for 0.5 h with stirring. The resulting mixture was put into a Teflon®-lined stainless steel autoclave (25 mL capacity) under autogenous pressure and heated to 165 °C for 72 h. The autoclave was then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 3.0 °C/h. Colorless rhombic sheet crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography were obtained; yield of 48%. The crystalline material is difficult to dissolve in water, methanol, ethanol, ether, acetonitrile, DMF or DMSO.

The Selected bond lengths (Å) and angles (°) of the complex [Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)]n are listed in Table 3.

Scheme 1 and Fig. 1 are the molecular structure of the cadmium complex, and Fig. 2 shows the packing diagram of the cadmium complex in a unit cell.

The Cd(II) ion is six-coordinate to form a octahedron. The Cd(II) ions lie across the centers of complex and respectively integrate with four neutral tryptophan molecules: two l-trp and two d-trp. The complex shows a two-dimensional structure along the bc orientation assembled by bridging the oxygen of the carboxyl and the cadmium ion into chains of ‘···–O–C–O–Cd–O–C–O–Cd···’ interactions (see Figs. 3, 4, 5). Each unit cell contains two [Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)] coordination units. l-trp and d-trp are chiral ligands in the complex, which crystallizes in centrosymmetric space group. In the molecular structure of [Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)]n, the cadmium ion is coordinated by two N atoms and two O atoms from a l-trp and a d-trp, respectively, and two O atoms from another two carboxy groups of adjacent position l-trp and d-trp moieties (Figs. 1, 2). The equatorial Cd–O bond lengths are Cd1–O1: 2.263 (3) Å, Cd1–O2: 2.350 (3) Å. The axial Cd–N distance is 2.324 (3) Å. The angles in the octahedron are ∠O1i–Cd1–O1 = ∠O2ii–Cd1–O2iii = 180.0 (13)°, ∠O1i–Cd1–O2ii = ∠O1–Cd1–O2iii = 85.80 (11)°, ∠O1–Cd1–O2ii = ∠O1i–Cd1–O2iii = 94.20 (11)°, ∠O1i–Cd1–N1i = ∠O1–Cd1–N1 = 75.31 (11)°, ∠O1–Cd1–N1i = ∠O1i–Cd1–N1 = 104.69 (11)°, ∠O2ii–Cd1–N1i = ∠O2iii–Cd1–N1 = 89.55 (11)°, ∠O2iii–Cd1–N1i = ∠O2ii–Cd1–N1 = 90.45 (11)°, ∠N1i–Cd1–N1 = 180.00 (10)°, respectively. The structure shows that each Cd(II) atom exhibits a slightly deformed octahedral environment with four oxygen atoms from four different l-trp and d-trp molecules in the equatorial plane, as well as two nitrogen atoms from l-trp and a d-trp molecules at the axial positions. Bonds lengths and angles agree with literature-accepted values. Since each Cd2+ ion coordinates with a pair of racemes, the complex is a mesomer. Consequently the crystallized coordination polymer has a centrosymmetric space group.

Results and Discussion

The Selected bond lengths (Å) and angles (°) of the complex [Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)]n are listed in Table 3.

Scheme 1 and Fig. 1 are the molecular structure of the cadmium complex, and Fig. 2 shows the packing diagram of the cadmium complex in a unit cell.

The Cd(II) ion is six-coordinate to form a octahedron. The Cd(II) ions lie across the centers of complex and respectively integrate with four neutral tryptophan molecules: two l-trp and two d-trp. The complex shows a two-dimensional structure along the bc orientation assembled by bridging the oxygen of the carboxyl and the cadmium ion into chains of ‘⋅⋅⋅-O-C-O-Cd-O-C-O-Cd⋅⋅⋅' interactions (see Figs. 3, 4, 5). Each unit cell contains two [Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)] coordination units. l-trp and d-trp are chiral ligands in the complex, which crystallizes in centrosymmetric space group. In the molecular structure of [Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)]n, the cadmium ion is coordinated by two N atoms and two O atoms from a l-trp and a d-trp, respectively, and two O atoms from another two carboxy groups of adjacent position l-trp and d-trp moieties (Figs. 1, 2). The equatorial Cd-O bond lengths are Cd1-O1: 2.263 (3) Å, Cd1-O2: 2.350 (3) Å. The axial Cd-N distance is 2.324 (3) Å. The angles in the octahedron are ∠O1i-Cd1-O1 = ∠O2ii-Cd1-O2iii = 180.0 (13)°, ∠O1i-Cd1-O2ii = ∠O1-Cd1-O2iii = 85.80 (11)°, ∠O1-Cd1-O2ii = ∠O1i-Cd1-O2iii = 94.20 (11)°, ∠O1i-Cd1-N1i = ∠O1-Cd1-N1 = 75.31 (11)°, ∠O1-Cd1-N1i = ∠O1i-Cd1-N1 = 104.69 (11)°, ∠O2ii-Cd1-N1i = ∠O2iii-Cd1-N1 = 89.55 (11)°, ∠O2iii-Cd1-N1i = ∠O2ii-Cd1-N1 = 90.45 (11)°, ∠N1i-Cd1-N1 = 180.00 (10)°, respectively. The structure shows that each Cd(II) atom exhibits a slightly deformed octahedral environment with four oxygen atoms from four different l-trp and d-trp molecules in the equatorial plane, as well as two nitrogen atoms from l-trp and a d-trp molecules at the axial positions. Bonds lengths and angles agree with literature-accepted values. Since each Cd2+ ion coordinates with a pair of racemes, the complex is a mesomer. Consequently the crystallized coordination polymer has a centrosymmetric space group.

elements.content: Interestingly, both l-trp and d-trp were observed in the complex although l-trp was used as the unique starting material. It is noteworthy that l-trp is not easy to racemize. Our findings indicate a positive correlation between racemization and pH, temperature or reaction time [23–27]. Although we do not have a complete explanation for the conversion of l-trp to d-trp, we speculate that, under the influence of steric hindrance and solvent, some l-trp is converted to d-trp in order to satisfy symmetry requirements. In fact, this assumption is confirmed experimentally since only [M(d-trp) (l-trp)]n is obtained when the water-thermal and organic-solvent thermal methods are used [28–34]. Furthermore, when l-trp is used, a mixture of DL-tryptophan crystals is observed in the presence of neodymium carbonate and the mixed solvent of MeOH and H2O.

Although we do not have a complete explanation for the conversion of l-trp to d-trp, we speculate that, under the influence of steric hindrance and solvent, some l-trp is converted to d-trp in order to satisfy symmetry requirements. In fact, this assumption is confirmed experimentally since only [M(d-trp) (l-trp)]n is obtained when the water-thermal and organic-solvent thermal methods are used [28-34]. Furthermore, when l-trp is used, a mixture of DL-tryptophan crystals is observed in the presence of neodymium carbonate and the mixed solvent of MeOH and H2O.

elements.content: The symmetry of [Cd(l-trp)2]n crystal structure is lower than that of [Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)]n since the latter is centrosymmetric. Relative to [Cd(l-trp)2]n and [Cd(d-trp)2]n, a lower energy and higher stability is achieved, which is attributed to the spatial arrangement of l-trp and d-trp in the [Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)]n crystal structure. Thus, there is enough pressure, temperature and reaction time under solvent-thermal conditions to transform l-trp to d-trp gradually and partially via an enamine intermediate [23, 24]. We reason that there is a dynamic equilibrium existed between l-trp and d-trp, and the equilibrium can readily shift to a more stable configuration by crystallization or precipitation from solution. Consequently, self-assembly that generates a supramolecular polymer, {[Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)]n}, may be a typical cooperative process.

elements.content: A novel two-dimensional double chain structure of cadmium (II), [Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)]n, was synthesized and structurally characterized. The complex crystallizes in a monoclinic system and belong to the P2(1)/c space group. Each Cd(II) atom is located in the center of a deformed octahedral configuration. The six vertexes of the deformed octahedron form a 4O + 2N coordination number environment with four oxygen atoms from four different l-trp and d-trp molecules; two nitrogen atoms from a l-trp and a d-trp molecule. Each Cd(II) ion coordinates with a pair of racemes, and the complex is a mesomer. The crystallized coordination polymer has a centrosymmetric space group.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A novel two-dimensional double chain structure of cadmium (II), [Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)]n, was synthesized and structurally characterized. The complex crystallizes in a monoclinic system and belong to the P2(1)/c space group. Each Cd(II) atom is located in the center of a deformed octahedral configuration. The six vertexes of the deformed octahedron form a 4O + 2N coordination number environment with four oxygen atoms from four different l-trp and d-trp molecules; two nitrogen atoms from a l-trp and a d-trp molecule. Each Cd(II) ion coordinates with a pair of racemes, and the complex is a mesomer. The crystallized coordination polymer has a centrosymmetric space group.

cln_elements.content: All the reagents were of AR grade and used without further purification. l-trp (1.0 mmol, 0.2043 g) was dissolved in methanol (10 mL) and stirred for 10 min at room temperature. Cadmium acetate dihydrate (0.5 mmol, 0.1337 g) was dissolved in methanol (10 mL) and added dropwise to the above solution for 0.5 h with stirring. The resulting mixture was put into a Teflon®-lined stainless steel autoclave (25 mL capacity) under autogenous pressure and heated to 165 °C for 72 h. The autoclave was then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 3.0 °C/h. Colorless rhombic sheet crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography were obtained; yield of 48%. The crystalline material is difficult to dissolve in water, methanol, ethanol, ether, acetonitrile, DMF or DMSO.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Synthesis of [Cd(l-trp) (d-trp)]n

All the reagents were of AR grade and used without further purification. l-trp (1.0 mmol, 0.2043 g) was dissolved in methanol (10 mL) and stirred for 10 min at room temperature. Cadmium acetate dihydrate (0.5 mmol, 0.1337 g) was dissolved in methanol (10 mL) and added dropwise to the above solution for 0.5 h with stirring. The resulting mixture was put into a Teflon®-lined stainless steel autoclave (25 mL capacity) under autogenous pressure and heated to 165 °C for 72 h. The autoclave was then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 3.0 °C/h. Colorless rhombic sheet crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography were obtained; yield of 48%. The crystalline material is difficult to dissolve in water, methanol, ethanol, ether, acetonitrile, DMF or DMSO.
